thread.title: China risk to UK ‘overblown’

title: China risk to UK ‘overblown’
text:
China risk to UK ‘overblown’, says BoE official Emily Cadman Ai show hits jarring note as Xi visit nears 
Warnings of the risks to the UK from the slowdown in China and emerging markets are overblown and should not derail interest rate rises, according to a member of the Bank of England’s rate-setting board. 
In a speech on Friday , Kristin Forbes said that while global economic risks and uncertainties have increased “the widespread pessimism is overstated”, adding that “much of the negative news that dominates headlines today should prove temporary”. 
Confirming her reputation as one of the more hawkish members of the Monetary Policy Committee, Ms Forbes said that the news on the international economy “has not caused me to adjust my prior expectations that the next move in UK interest rates will be up and that it will occur sooner rather than later”. 
After a summer of turmoil in the markets, investors have been getting increasingly unnerved about the economic outlook, amid more signs that growth in China is slowing . But Ms Forbes noted that the downgraded growth rates for emerging market economies is still likely to be around twice as fast as in advanced economies. 
The UK only has “limited direct exposure” to emerging markets, Ms Forbes stressed, adding the risks “appear manageable”. 
“This is especially true when considered relative to the strength of the UK’s domestic-led expansion — which shows all signs of continuing, even if at a more moderate pace than in the earlier stages of the recovery.” 
Ms Forbes added that the emerging markets were a significant opportunity for British business, with the rise of the middle classes likely to increase demand for high-quality UK brands. 
While the markets have pushed out their expectations for the first interest rate rise into 2017, most city economists still have a late-spring 2016 rise pencilled into their forecasts. 
Last week, BoE governor Mark Carney reiterated his stance that the decision on when to raise rates is likely to come into “sharp relief” around the turn of the year. Bank forecasts are for inflation to begin picking up notably from the current near-zero levels in the spring. This is when the impact of the sustained fall in oil prices begins to work its way out of the year-on-year comparison. Related Topics Copyright The Financial Times Limited 2015.
